awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: Homotopy Renormalization of Topological Field Theories
awd_abstract_narration:
Mathematics inspired by physics has successfully provided the background and the language for most sophisticated areas of modern physics.  In this project the principal investigators aim to create new algebraic and geometric tools helping to formulate ideas and methods of quantum physics in a precise mathematical way.  Specifically, the team will combine its members' past experience and achievements to construct new Topological Quantum Field Theories for manifolds with additional structures. Inspired by Witten's Chern-Simons theory and invariants of 3-manifolds that are known now as Witten-Reshetikhin-Turaev invariants, the principal investigators will explore their new Field Theories with the objective to find physical definitions for the resulting topological invariants of manifolds.  This work is stimulated by several fundamental examples and will open the door to new research avenues in algebra, topology, geometry, mathematical physics, and related areas of mathematics. The broader impacts of the project belong to two main categories: mentoring and outreach.  The members of the research team are currently mentoring a total of twelve PhD students.  They will advise graduate students on projects related to the main objectives of the grant.  The outreach component is to organize several workshops and conferences aimed at developing communication and collaborative research between participants of the project, establishing scientific connections with other mathematicians, as well as fostering broader applications of this work.

In 1999, Turaev introduced Homotopy Quantum Field Theories (HQFTs), which are generalizations of Topological Quantum Field Theories (TQFTs) studied by Schwartz, Witten, and Atiyah.  HQFTs produce topological invariants of manifolds furnished with extra data that add supplementary topology/geometry to the context of TQFTs.  Most of the theory of quantum invariants and HQFTs involves monoidal categories which have certain additional properties like being semi-simple.  In various collaborations started in 2005,   the team members developed a theory of re-normalized Quantum Invariants that derives non-trivial topological invariants from non-semi-simple categories.  In this project the principal investigators will further use renormalization to develop non-trivial HQFTs, based on the examples coming from the theory of unrestricted quantum group.  These new HQFTs should share the strength and the new features of the re-normalized Quantum Invariants.  The principal investigators will further search for a physical interpretation of these new invariants.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: FOCUSED RESEARCH GROUPS IN MATH SCIENCES

por.por_cntn:
Around 1990, a brand new field of mathematics (and mathematical physics) research emerged, known as quantum topology. It was initiated by concurrent discoveries in mathematics and physics that showed that knots (knotted loops in three-dimensional space) could be characterized and classified by probabilities of knotted vortices arising in a three-dimensional quantum field theory. It was thus realized that *quantum* physics could be used to efficiently characterize the shape (topology) of geometric objects - hence quantum topology. The original discoveries beautifully tied together physical quantum field theory (a QFT known as Chern-Simons theory), the mathematics and physics of vertex operator algebras, and purely mathematical structure of so-called quantum groups. 

Since the 1990?s, both mathematics and physics approaches to quantum topology have evolved and been developed by thousands of researchers. They have also been applied to a broad array of other fields, most notably condensed matter and quantum computing. (Quantum topology forms the basis for quantum error correction.) However, the physics and mathemathics have not always evolved together.

A significant development in mathematics was the generalization of quantum groups to a so-called ?non-semisimple? setting. This generalization was very natural, but also very difficult to codify precisely in mathematical terms - it was not yet complete at the time that our FRG collaboration began. Independently, in the mathematical and physical study of vertex operator algebras, a vast generalization of the algebras used for quantum topology in the 1990?s was introduced, so-called ?logarithmic? vertex operator algebras. Some links between non-semisimple quantum groups and logarithmic vertex operator algebras had begun to appear in the last two decades, but this was also incomplete. Finally, many three-dimensional quantum field theories that (in principle) could match the structure of non-semisimple quantum groups had been studied, but a direct link with non-semisimple quantum groups had never been made.

Our FRG collaboration was established to ambitiously tackle these open problems. It brought together a broad team of experts from both mathematics and physics in order to (on one hand) complete the rigorous mathematical definition/codification of topological invariants arising from non-semisimple quantum groups; and (on the other hand) identify for the first time a physical framework for these invariants using quantum field theory. We aimed to fully upgrade the founding discoveries of quantum topology from the 1990?s to a modern, non-semisimple setting.

We succeeded, accomplishing our most important foundational goals, while inspiring a brand new set of open questions to be explored in future years (or decades). On the pure mathematics side, a complete framework was established to produce new topological invariants detecting the shape of knots and three-manifolds (three-dimensional curved spaces) using non-semisimple quantum groups. My part of the collaboration specifically involved the connection to quantum field theory. My collaborators and I showed, in a series of two papers, that certain supersymmetric three-dimensional gauge theories - being very actively studied by a completely different section of the scientific community - are directly related to non-semisimple quantum groups. Along the way, we brought in another expert (Thomas Creutzig from the University of Alberta) to help us firmly connect logarithmic vertex operator algebras to *both* non-semisimple quantum groups and our supersymmetric three-dimensional gauge theories.

From a physical perspective, the ?non-semisimple? aspect of the new invariants has a somewhat intuitive interpretation. It means that vortices in the three-dimensional theories we study can bind to each other, forming so-called ?bound states.? In a condensed-matter or quantum-computing setting, one would say that there are bound states of anyons. We hope that our explicit realizations of bound-state phenomena might find some use in condensed matter or quantum computing in the future.

Our collaboration held a weeklong workshop at UC Berkeley, ?New Developments in Quantum Topology? (June 2019), which brought together a large sector of the mathematics and physics communities working on related ideas. Our workshop included pedagogical sessions focused on the training of graduate students. My own research as part of the FRG collaboration directly helped to train two graduate students, who have now both obtained their PhD?s and have gone on to postdoctoral positions pursuing new research of their own.
